title: Chemical Burns
summary: Emergency treatment for burns caused by acids, alkalis, or other corrosive chemicals on skin or in eyes.

steps.title: Ensure Safety First
steps.description: Protect yourself from the chemical. Wear gloves and protective equipment if available. Ensure the area is well-ventilated. Remove the person from the chemical source. Call 911 for severe burns.

steps.title: Remove Contaminated Clothing
steps.description: Quickly and carefully remove any clothing or jewelry that has been contaminated with the chemical. Cut clothing off rather than pulling it over the head. Be careful not to spread the chemical to unaffected areas.

steps.title: Flush with Water Immediately
steps.description: Rinse the burned area with cool running water for at least 20 minutes. Use a gentle stream to avoid spreading the chemical. For dry chemicals, brush off excess powder before flushing with water.

steps.title: Special Care for Eye Burns
steps.description: If chemicals are in the eyes, flush immediately with water for at least 20 minutes. Have the person remove contact lenses if possible. Hold eyelids open and flush from inner corner outward.

steps.title: Cover the Burn
steps.description: After thorough flushing, loosely cover the burn with a dry, sterile dressing or clean cloth. Do not apply creams, ointments, or home remedies. Keep the dressing loose to avoid pressure on burned skin.

steps.title: Monitor and Document
steps.description: Monitor for shock symptoms. Try to identify the chemical involved and save the container or take a photo of the label for medical personnel. Note the time of exposure and duration of flushing.

warnings: Some chemicals react with water - only brush off dry chemicals if you know water is safe
Never neutralize acids with bases or vice versa
Do not apply ice directly to chemical burns
Chemical burns may appear minor at first but worsen over hours
whenToSeekHelp: All chemical burns require medical evaluation
Burns to eyes, face, hands, feet, or genitals
Large burns or burns that appear deep
Difficulty breathing or signs of inhalation injury
preventionTips: Always wear appropriate protective equipment when handling chemicals
Read and follow all chemical safety labels
Keep chemicals in original containers with labels intact
Have emergency eyewash stations in areas where chemicals are used
Know the location of safety showers in work areas
